p: A previous study by de Ara√∫jo et al. [ 11] was in accordance with our findings. They showed that orally administered essential oil of A. zerumbet, at doses of 100 mg/kg and 300 mg/kg, had anti-nociceptive effects against acetic acid-induced writing, formalin-induced paw licking effect, and increased the latency in the hot plate test. They also showed that the central anti-nociceptive effect in the hot plate test was partially mediated through opiate receptors, as it was partially blocked by naloxone, an opioid antagonist.
